newsitem.title: USA: NYS ranks cities with tax-exempt property - paper.
newsitem.headline: NYS ranks cities with tax-exempt property - paper.

text.p: Watervliet in Albany County, N.Y., led the list of the state's cities with the most tax-exempt property, though it was closely followed by Ogdensburg, the Times Union said in its Thursday edition.

Only nine of the state's 62 cities lost more than half of their tax base to exemptions, but three of them are in the Capital Region, the paper said, citing 1994 data released by the Office of Real Property Services.
Cities with high levels of tax-exempt property are forced to make up the loss in revenues by other means, such as higher local property taxes that are paid by homeowners and businesses.
The paper said that New York state pays $98 million in local property taxes on about 20,000 parcels in 49 counties, though none of these funds go to the city of Albany, the state's capital.
